article.description:
Once again, Julius Page was one of
Pittsburgh's top scorers in a relatively easy victory -- but he
saved his best shots for after the game.
article.headline: After sluggish start, Panthers run away with it
article.linkText: Pitt starts very slow, then blows out Ark.-Pine Bluff
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Once again, Julius Page was one of
Pittsburgh's top scorers in a relatively easy victory -- but he
saved his best shots for after the game.

	   Toree Morris scored seven consecutive points early in an
18-point run that broke open an unexpectedly tight game and the
fifth-ranked Panthers went on to beat Arkansas-Pine Bluff 89-49
Saturday night.

	   Afterward, Page, who scored 14 points, complained the Panthers
weren't focused, were playing selfishly and should have come into
the game with more intensity.

	   ''As long as we continue to let teams stay around, this will
catch up to us in the Big East,'' Page said.

	   Pitt coach Ben Howland doesn't necessarily agree, although he
was unhappy his team came out with so little regard for
Arkansas-Pine Bluff, which has lost 30 of its last 32 games.

	   ''Last year we didn't have one game where we didn't respect our
opponents,'' he said. ''I told them at the half that those guys
didn't fear us, and we've got to do the things we need to do to
win, whether we're playing Pine Bluff or Georgetown. We're not the
Lakers, we're the Pitt Panthers and nobody's going to lay down for
us.''

	   The Lions (0-4), picked to finish last in the SWAC, lost their
first three games to Georgia Tech, Memphis and Illinois by a
combined 115 points, yet led much of the first half while shooting
8-of-13 from 3-point range.

	   Pittsburgh (3-0) didn't take the lead for good until Page scored
on a driving layup and a dunk on successive possessions to make it
28-24.

	   Pitt star Brandin Knight, a third-team All-American, was only
4-of-12 during an 11-point night, but hit a 3-pointer to make it
37-30 at halftime. The Panthers led only 42-38 with just over 15
minutes remaining before holding the Lions scoreless for more than
seven minutes during a 25-2 run that included the 18 consecutive
points.

	   ''Honestly, I don't think about our ranking,'' Howland said.
''Kansas was No. 2 and they lost twice ... (teams) don't care what
we're ranked.''

	   Morris got Pitt going, dunking twice on what essentially was the
same Pitt possession early in the run. He missed a free throw then,
after Pitt retained possession, dunked again off a missed shot.

	   ''I knew we weren't playing the way we're supposed to play,''
Morris said. ''We didn't expect them to come out making those shots
they did. I knew we had to pick it up, and I told myself to do
something to get some excitement into the team.''

	   Picking up its play after the Morris dunks, Pitt outscored
Arkansas-Pine Bluff 52-19 in the second half, shooting 49.2 percent
for the game despite going 5-of-23 on 3-pointers.

	   Chevy Troutman came off the bench to lead Pitt with 15 points,
with Jaron Brown adding 13 points and Morris 10. Donatas Zavackas
had 11 rebounds as Pitt outrebounded the Lions 50-25.

	   Billy Hall scored 15 points but Arkansas-Pine Bluff, one of the
nation's worst Division I teams, lost its 11th in a row since last
season. The schedule doesn't ease up for the Lions, who still must
face Kansas State, Miami, Mississippi and Iowa State before
starting conference play.

	   Arkansas-Pine Bluff coach Van Holt left without talking to
reporters.
